timeline.subject: Bastienne Brihey

accomplices_named.context: Bastienne's daughter, named during her confession as a witch like her

accomplices_named.name: Georgeatte
accomplices_named.context: Bastienne's daughter, named during her confession as a witch like her; sentenced to death 26 November 1619

prior_accusations.accuser_name: Ysabeau, veuve en troisieme noces de Nicolas Demenge Richard
prior_accusations.context: During her trial in November 1615, said she encountered Bastienne and her daughter Marie on way back from Sabbat 3 years earlier; both were reputed witches

notable_quotes.speaker: Bastienne Brihey
notable_quotes.french: que par le nom de dieu elle l'avoit emmenée, mais si elle pouvoit revenir elle ne l'en remeneroit jamais
notable_quotes.english: by the name of God she had taken her away, but if she could come back she would never bring her back again
notable_quotes.context: Angry threat when servant Jannon took Marie away without permission

notable_quotes.speaker: Bastienne Brihey
notable_quotes.french: Marie sa femme s'en mesle non pas, qu'elle mouche son né (en prenant le sien entre ses doigts, et bessant la teste) tout bas, tout bas
notable_quotes.english: Marie his wife is not involved in it, she wipes her nose (taking her own between her fingers and lowering her head) very quietly, very quietly
notable_quotes.context: When asked if she blamed herself for Demenge Didier Plaid's illness - cryptic suggestion that if she was a witch, Marie was one too

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Didier Plaid
notable_quotes.context: What Bastienne called him during quarrel over inheritance

notable_quotes.speaker: Bastienne Brihey
notable_quotes.french: Antoine nous sommes malades tous deux, il fault adviser lequel veult guerir l'autre
notable_quotes.english: Antoine we are both sick, we must decide which one wants to cure the other
notable_quotes.context: When visiting sick child Antoine Doron

notable_quotes.speaker: Bastienne Brihey
notable_quotes.french: mon fils est tu encor par icy
notable_quotes.english: my son are you still around here
notable_quotes.context: Said to child after witness warned him not to eat apple Bastienne had given

notable_quotes.speaker: Bastienne Brihey
notable_quotes.french: tu deviens bien grand Antoine, dieu t'amende
notable_quotes.english: you are getting very big Antoine, God improve you
notable_quotes.context: Said when touching Antoine Doron's son, after which he became ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Georgette (daughter)
notable_quotes.french: qu'est ce qu'elle diroit au malin esprit lors qu'il la viendroit trouver
notable_quotes.english: what would she say to the evil spirit when it would come to find her
notable_quotes.context: According to Marie, what Georgette said their mother had asked when she was 'fol et frenetique'

warned him as child to keep away from their land because of reputation

story about how Bastienne might have been responsible for burning of his foot

hearsay_chains.source: mother-in-law Barbon veuve Mongeon Didier Marie
hearsay_chains.content: story about Bastienne handling chemise and child falling out of cot
sister Georgette told Marie that mother was 'fol et frenetique' and had asked what she would say to the evil spirit
suggested loss of heifer might have been result of quarrel

emotional_state_notes: During interrogation, Bastienne seemed uncertain and inconsistent - said daughters were witches then seemed unsure
Georgette 'en pleurant, et larmoyant demesurement' (crying and weeping excessively) denied being a witch when confronted
Officials questioned whether Bastienne understood questions being put to her
Decided she answered pertinently without 'simplicité et imbecillité' she had been simulating

extraction_metadata.notes: This trial has extensive witness testimony (27 witnesses) with detailed accounts of harms, quarrels, and threats. Bastienne confessed to being a witch and implicated her daughters Marie and Georgette. The case shows a long-standing reputation (up to 20 years), multiple animal deaths attributed to witchcraft following quarrels, and several cases of human illness/death. Notable features include: healing episodes where Bastienne cured victims by sharing food; her son-in-law Demenge Didier Plaid testifying against her despite family relationship; incident at Epinal market with toad; property confiscation mentioned (415 francs). Both Bastienne and Georgette were sentenced to death. The trial demonstrates typical patterns of accusation following quarrels, threats, and subsequent misfortunes, with strong economic context around property disputes and animal losses.
